"FRENCH DRAFT OF PROPOSED ANGLOnPEENOH TREATY'' Tho French Ambassador called on me by appointment onthe evening of the 26th in order to hand to me MonsieurPoinoare"!s proposals with regard to the contemplated Pactbetween Great Britain and France, and to offer certain ex-planations as to tho views of his Government thereon. Commencing by an expression of the warm desire ofMonsieur Poincare to cement the friendly relations betweenthe two countries by the conclusion of such an Agreement, heproceeded to oall my attention to the principal features ofthe Frenoh draft, which he explained in the following fashion. Tho British draft prepared at Cannes was of a uni-lateral character inasmuch as it had contemplated & guarantee against German aggression given try Great Britain to Francewithout any corresponding obligation cn the part of the latter. Monsieur Poincare proposed in Article 1 that theongagemont should be reciprocal and that France should equallyengage to come to the aid of Great Britain with all her naval,military and air forces in tho event of an unprovoked attack doby Germany, just as we were prepared to/in the oase of asimilar attack upon Franco. ^when I enquired the reason for this change, the ambassador told me that although it might be unlikely thata German attack upon Great Britain would take place, yet itwas hardly consistent with tho solf-respect of the FrenchGovernment to accept what had the air of being a favour, with-out entering into any corresponding obligation themselves.He felt that it would be better that the two nations shouldbe- put en the footing of absolute equality in the matter. I said that in this respect as in all others Ishould not like at the first moment, without harring examined /the the text or consulted my colleagues, to pledge the final views of the British Government upon the matter. At the same time, if we could do anything that would remove from the Agreement anything that was likely to he in- jurious to the "amour propre" of our great Ally, I thought the British Government would he entirely willing to con- sider the point in a most friendly spirit,, The Ambassador then proceeded to explain with a good deal of fulness the proposed second article in the French draft under which, differing from the British pro- posal, which had laid down that in the case of a violation of Articles 42 and 43 of the Treaty of "Versailles Great Britain and France should concert together, the infringe- ment of those Articles was to be considered as constituting a direct act of aggression against the security of France. He pointed out that, from the French point of view, the promise to consult or concert in the case in question was an altogether insufficient security against German aggression, and that Germany required to be deterred by something much more efficacious. He was aware that this proposal, which had leaked out in the newspapers, had met with a good deal of criticism, on the ground inter alia that Great Britain%iight be involved thereby in hostilities against Germany arising out of some petty local incident on the frontier for which the Germans might not be wholly to blame, and he went on to explain that such ?/as not the least the sort of case that his Government had in view. It; would be easy to provide that if owing to an incident of such a oharacter on the frontiers of the Hhineland German police measures were required to be taken by Germany, she should . /be be at liberty to carry them out after information to andin concert with the Allies. What his Government had in view were direct andunprovoked acts of aggression upon the frontier of aserious nature. I replied at once that the Ambassador must notbe surprised if the British Government took serious objection to this proposal, for, after all, what was it that he proposed? What had been contemplated at Cannesand what the British Parliament and British people were,I believed, prepared to support, was that in the event ofunprovoked aggression upon France by Germany, that is a repetition of the experience which she had before endured,Great Britain, regarding her eastern frontier as in a sense the outer frontier of Great Britain herself, would come to her aid. Now it was proposed that any violation of two particular Articles of the Treaty of Versailles,which had been signed by all the Powers and the duty ofcarrying out which belonged to all the Powers, should beregarded as if it wore a matter that concerned GreatBritain and France alono, and that we should take uponourselves the obligation to sustain these Articles of theTreaty by action which might involve this country in themost terrible of obligations. Such was an obligationwhich I did not think the British people would be likelyto accept. Moreover, was not the proposal to assume itentirely inconsistent with the new theory upon which itwas generally believed that the policy of Europe was tobe basod after the War? Everywhere it had been preachedthat the old policy of rival groupings of great powers 1 /was was to disappear and to bo replaced by a concord of tlienations6 By another part of the Treaty of Versaillesthe League of Nations had been placed in charge of this new conception and was already endeavouring with limited powers to carry it out Now apparently it was proposedthat instead of the Triple Alliance, which had, we thought,disappeared altogether, there should be set up a newDouble Alliance between Great Britain and France, whichas the most powerful nations would dominate the scone,assuming the responsibilities which did not belong tothem alone, and claiming a sort of hegemony in Europe, I did not think that such a proposal was con-sis tent either with the principles of the Treaty ofVersailles or with our own conception of the duties de-volving upon Great Britain,, The Ambassador replied by saying in the firstplace that he thought that such an alliance would of itself have the effect of inducing the other powers ofEurope to enter into close and friendly relations vdtheach other, and that so far from desiring to ignore theleague of Nations, the French Government would be quitewilling that the League of Nations should be brought inat any stage that might be thought desirable. Informationof the intended action might be conveyed to the Leagueof Nations. Their approval or sanction might be soughtand, so far from the projected alliance between GreatBritain and France constituting a menace to Europe, hethought that it would tend to a consolidation of inter-national relations, the other Powers grouping themselvesround the two principal parties and being brought into / their their engagements in some manner which he did not clearlydefine * I replied that Monsieur Briand had talked agood deal in a similar somewhat nebulous fashion, butI had never been able clearly to understand in what waythis association between thsr two Powers and the rest ofEurope was to be effected. I thought that it would "bomuch better and safer to regard the proposed Anglo-FrenchAgreement from the angle from whioh Yre had hithertoapproached it, and to confine it to the contingenciespreviously discussed, I could not, therefore, encourage him to thinkthat my Government would welcome this addition to thedraft. The Ambassador then passed to Article 3 of theFrench draft which proposes the maintenance of "uneentente.constante" between the General Staffs of the twocountries, with a view to secure the efficacious fulfilment of the engagements already"described. He explained to me that this Article was de-signed to meet the objections against a military con-vention which had been definitely formulated by theBritish Prime Minister. All that the French Governmentsuggested was that there should be concerted actionbetween the two General Staffs of a character somewhat similar to that which had existed in a more informalfashion before the War. The two Staffs would meet and exchange information and make reports as to the mannerin which their respective obligations could be dischargedin the event of the necessity arising. 6 P I said at once that I did not quite see whya special article in the Treaty should be required inorder to provide for these conversations which mustnecessarily be of a confidential character, and whichcould apparently quite well be pursued by existingmethods. The Count de Saint-Aulaire admitted in reply that this Article was introduced with a view to impressthe Germans with the seriousness of the situation andwith the reality of the danger to which they would be exposed in the event of hostilities. , I said that our Military Authorities wouldrequire to bo heard upon the matter, but I did not quitesee the point of introducing an article, the solepurpose of which appeared to be to act as a bogey tofrighten the Germans, In a Note which His Excellency left with mecontaining the heads of his argument, he explained thatthis proposal of his Government was intended as a substitute for the regime of the Cologne Conference of1920. It was added that as in the latter case theFrench and British Staffs should contemplate an eventualco-operation with the Belgian Army. His Excellency then passed on to Article 4,which provides for common action between the French andBritish Governments on all questions likely to jeopardisepeace or "porter atteinte h 1'Ordre general etabli parles traites de paix dont ils sont signataires." Thetwo Powers were to examine together the proper steps tobe taken to ensure with promptitude a pacific and /equitable equitable settlement of the question concerned. In his expository Note this Article was explained by the Ambassador as implying the indirectguarantee for Prance which had not appeared in theBritish draft. Its object was described as being toprovide for a rapid agreement between Prance and GreatBritain with a view to facilitate the ulterior collectiveintervention of mich a body as the League of Nations. The Ambassador explained to me personallythat this Artiole had been framed in order to meet the objection which had been raised to a possible call formilitary action by Great Britain under the Treaty, inthe- event of German aggression upon Poland or any of the theoutlying States of/Eastern parts of Europe. It had been pointed out that British interest in thorp was on anentirely different plane from their interest in the franco-Belgian frontier, and that no British Governmentcould accept obligations of so vague and compromising a character. Accordingly, this Article had been suggested, ind it meant that, in the event of any such situation arising, the two great Allied Powers would at onceconsult together and then, if they were so agreed, would act in concert with the League of Nations in finding apacific solution. Here again, I said to the iimbassador, i thought that objections would probably be entertainedto putting so ambiguous an Article into the Treaty. To this he replied by suggesting that if wecould not find a place for it there, ?/e might prefer togive the assurance asked for in the form of a letter. /This *3 8 V* This I pointed out would he inconsistent both with our practice, and with the obligation which we hadall entered into as regards publicity with the Leagueof Nations. Finally, the French Government asked that the duration of the Treaty, which we had fixed at 10 years in the British draft, should be extended to 30 years, the argument being advanced in the explanatory Note that, asthe so-called "Naval holiday" is to terminate in 10 years,it would be to the interests of Great Britain to maintainher engagement with France for a longer period, becauseof its effect upon the question of naval armaments. With regard to the proposed time limit I ex-pressed some surprise at the term which was now suggestedby the French Government. I said that 1 thought mycolleagues would have been willing - if a good case couldbe made out - to contemplate an extension to 15 years or some similar period, and that I had been led by the press to anticipate that such a request would be'made. Nowhorehad I seen the term of 30 years mentioned, and I thoughtit extremely unlikaly that the British Government would agree to such a period. Having listened to the above exposition "by theFrench Ambassador, I then asked him what were the viewsof Monsieur Poincare with regard to the manner in whichthe discussions upon it should take place. monsieur poincare" had been reported in the French Press as holdingthe view - which he had repeated both to Mr, Lloyd Georgeand myself - that the Paot between Great Britain andFrance, which we were now discussing, should not be /concluded concluded until the main preliminary questions uponwhich we were not altogether united had been moved outof the path - in other words, that the Agreement shouldbe the final rather than the first stage in our negotiations. Such, I said, had also been the viewexpounded by Mrs Lloyd George to Monsieur Briand atCannes where, without laying down precise conditions,the Prime Minister had indicated that we should roquireto be satisfied as to the settlement of the Near eastern question., the Tangier question, the question of theeconomic restoration of Europe, and the question of submarines, before we could accept the larger obligationsentailed by the new Treaty. There was a good deal, i thought, to be said for this point of view, which after all was the precise method which had been followed byLord Lansdowne in 1904, On that occasion the points at issue between the two Governments had been dealtwith - and as far as possible settled - one by one,culminating in a final agreement covering the wholeground. It was with the object of removing one of theseimpediments that I was going to Paris next week Ihoped that other obstacles might be removed in asimilar way, and in the interval there would be plenty of time to discuss such modifications in the draft treaty as were required. Greatly to my surprise the Ambassador informed me that such was not the view which he believed now tobe entertained by the French premier. On the contrary,the latter hoped that the Agreement might be concludedbefore the Genoa Conference took place, and his decision /as *J 10 *-*as regards attending it would no. doubt be iiafluenced toa largo extent by the degree to which his hopes werefulfilledo I said at once that it seemed to me quite out ofthe question that the question of the Pact eould besettled in the next five weeks before any substantial progress had been made in the solution of the othermatters, and that I preferred on the whole what I had understood to be the earlier method of Monsieur l'oineare. This disclosure, however, on the part of the ambassador is on indication of the extreme importance which the French Government attach to the conclusion ofthe Pact,, upon which the existence of Monsieur Poincare'*S ministry may be said in faiSt to depend, and left me withthe impression that while we hold it in suspense, as wehave every reason for doing in view of.the suggestedextension given to it by Monsieur Poincare, we may findin it a powerful lever for securing a favourable settle-rnent of the other issues.
